Le [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]ferrovie[\LINK] richiedono carbone, per esempio.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lavoratori[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, i principali miglioramenti sono quelli realizzati dai [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]lavoratori[\LINK] creati nelle città. Queste unità non possono combattere, non possono creare nuove città, ma possono costruire fattorie, strade e miniere, necessarie per permettere alle città di diventare ancora più grandi e potenti. Una civiltà non può fiorire e crescere senza un numero sufficiente di lavoratori.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Chiatte[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]chiatte[\LINK] sono simili ai lavoratori, nel senso che possono costruire miglioramenti sull'acqua: navi da pesca, baleniere e, successivamente, piattaforme petrolifere. C'è comunque una sostanziale differenza tra chiatte e lavoratori: una chiatta si esaurisce completamente quando termina di costruire un miglioramento. Hai bisogno di costruire una chiatta per ogni miglioramento in mare che vuoi realizzare (al contrario, i lavoratori non si "esauriscono" quando terminano di costruire dei miglioramenti).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Costruzione di miglioramenti[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Per costruire un miglioramento, muovi un lavoratore nella casella che vuoi migliorare: le azioni disponibili per quel lavoratore vengono visualizzate come pulsanti azione per quella unità. Se la tua civiltà soddisfa i requisiti di tecnologie e risorse necessari per quel miglioramento, e se quel miglioramento può essere costruito in quella casella, comparirà il pulsante a esso relativo per quel lavoratore. Clicca sul miglioramento che vuoi costruire e il lavoratore si metterà all'opera (se il miglioramento è evidenziato in grigio, significa che al momento non può essere costruito. Se sposti il mouse sopra di esso potrai leggere che cosa ti manca per poterlo realizzare).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Costruzione di strade e ferrovie:[\BOLD] puoi costruire [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]strade[\LINK] e [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]ferrovie[\LINK] in uno dei seguenti due modi possibili: puoi costruire manualmente la strada, un blocco alla volta, oppure utilizzare il comando "Strada per", nel quale basta cliccare la casella di destinazione; il lavoratore calcolerà automaticamente la strada più breve per raggiungerla, e comincerà a costruirla senza attendere ulteriori istruzioni (attenzione: questo metodo richiede meno tempo da parte tua, ma i tuoi lavoratori potrebbero in alcuni casi scegliere una strada ottimale diversa da quella che avevi in mente). Leggi la sezione relativa al [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]movimento[\LINK] per gli effetti che su di esso hanno le strade.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Tempo di Costruzione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]I miglioramenti richiedono uno o più turni per essere portati a termine. Il tempo di costruzione può variare a seconda della [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Forma di governo[\LINK] adottata in quella zona, mentre alcune particolari [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]tecnologie[\LINK] possono ridurre i tempi di costruzione. Infine, due o più lavoratori possono essere assegnati alla costruzione del medesimo miglioramento, dimezzando all'incirca il tempo di costruzione complessivo.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Interrompere una costruzione[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Puoi interrompere la creazione di un miglioramento in qualunque momento, basta cliccare sul Lavoratore che lo sta costruendo e dargli nuovi ordini.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Saccheggio dei miglioramenti[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le unità militari possono distruggere i miglioramenti che si trovano su territorio neutrale o su quello di una civiltà con cui sei in guerra. Per farlo, sposta l'unità sul miglioramento e clicca il pulsante "Saccheggio" (questa operazione utilizzerà uno dei punti movimento dell'unità). Potresti anche essere ricompensato con il bottino! Se in una casella sono presenti più miglioramenti (una strada e una miniera, ad esempio), l'unità ne distruggerà uno per turno. Tieni presente che i [LINK=CONCEPT_BARBARIANS]Barbari[\LINK] saranno ben contenti di saccheggiare i tuoi miglioramenti, se solo ne avranno l'opportunità.
TEXT.Spanish: Los asentamientos humanos sobreviven gracias a los recursos naturales que tienen disponibles en el terreno circundante. Al principio pueden hacerlo sin "trabajar la tierra": basta con que cosechen frutos secos y bayas silvestres en los bosques cercanos, mientras los cazadores abaten a cualquier animal que encuentren en el lugar. No obstante, tales recursos locales suelen ser finitos y, a medida que crezca la población de un asentamiento, deberá mejorar su capacidad de procurarse el sustento o morirá de hambre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Con el tiempo, el hombre ha desarrollado técnicas sofisticadas para obtener cada vez más recursos de la tierra: construye granjas para aumentar el suministro de alimentos, abre minas para obtener metales y combustible, edifica molinos de agua para aprovechar la fuerza de los ríos y "mejora" la tierra, haciéndola capaz de sostener a una población cada vez mayor. De hecho, la capacidad humana para obtener cada vez más recursos con menos personas es la base de toda civilización: si un hombre puede generar bastantes alimentos para mantener a dos, el segundo puede dedicarse a la escritura, a pintar un cuadro o a construir una catedral.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ubicación de las mejoras[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Las mejoras que beneficien directamente a ciudades concretas deben encontrarse dentro del [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]radio urbano[\LINK] de dicha ciudad, mientras que las que permitan que la civilización acceda a ciertos [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]recursos[\LINK] pueden estar en cualquier lugar dentro de sus [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]fronteras culturales[\LINK] (aunque suele ser mejor si también están dentro del radio urbano de una ciudad).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Disponibilidad de las mejoras[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Hay muchas mejoras que solo pueden construirse en lugares concretos: las minas, por ejemplo, se han de construir en las colinas (o encima de ciertos [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]recursos[\LINK]), mientras que las granjas solo pueden levantarse donde haya disponible agua dulce (hasta que se investigue la [LINK=CIVIC_CIVIL_SERVICE]administración pública[\LINK]). Además, todas las mejoras tienen un requisito tecnológico: por ejemplo, no puedes construir granjas hasta que tu civilización haya descubierto la [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]agricultura[\LINK]. Por último, ciertas mejoras exigen que tengas acceso a determinados recursos. Por ejemplo, los [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]ferrocarriles[\LINK] requieren carbón.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Trabajadores[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]En Civilization IV, la mayoría de las mejoras las construyen los [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]trabajadores[\LINK] que se crean en las ciudades. Estas unidades no pueden luchar ni crear nuevas ciudades, pero pueden construir las granjas, carreteras y minas necesarias para mantenerlas, con lo que se van haciendo mayores y más poderosas. Una civilización no puede florecer ni crecer si no cuenta con suficientes trabajadores.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Barcos faeneros[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]barcos faeneros[\LINK] se parecen a los trabajadores en que pueden construir mejoras en el agua: barcos pesqueros, barcos balleneros y, por último, plataformas petrolíferas. Sin embargo, hay algo que los diferencia enormemente, ya que un barco faenero se "gasta" al construir una mejora. Tendrás que fletar uno por cada mejora que desees realizar en el mar (los trabajadores no se gastan al construir mejoras).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Construir mejoras[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Para construir una mejora, lleva a un trabajador a la casilla que quieras mejorar. Las acciones disponibles para ese trabajador aparecerán en la sección "botón de la unidad" en la pantalla principal. Si tu civilización cumple los requisitos de tecnología y recursos para esa mejora y ésta puede construirse en esa casilla, la mejora aparecerá en el botón de la unidad del trabajador. Haz clic en la mejora y el trabajador empezará a construirla (si está sombreada, es que no puedes hacerla en ese momento; pasa el cursor por encima de ella para ver qué te falta).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construir carreteras y ferrocarriles:[\BOLD] Puedes construir [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]carreteras[\LINK] y [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]ferrocarriles[\LINK] de dos maneras: construyéndolos a mano, casilla a casilla; o usando la orden "Ir en ruta a", con la que, tras hacer clic en ella, deberás hacer clic en la casilla objetivo. El trabajador calculará la ruta más corta y construirá la carretera que lleve hasta allí sin necesidad de más órdenes (ten cuidado porque este método te supone menos trabajo pero a veces puede que los trabajadores no elijan lo que tú consideras que es la ruta óptima). Ver [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Movimiento[\LINK] para saber los efectos que las carreteras tienen en él.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Tiempo de construcción[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Terminar las mejoras lleva uno o más turnos. El tiempo de construcción varía en función de los [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]principios[\LINK] que hayas dispuesto, y ciertas [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]tecnologías[\LINK] también pueden acortarlo. Por último, dos o más trabajadores pueden construir a la vez la misma mejora, lo que acorta el tiempo de construcción aproximadamente a la mitad.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Interrumpir la construcción[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]En cualquier momento puedes dejar de trabajar en una mejora: basta con que hagas clic en el trabajador que la esté construyendo y le des nuevas órdenes.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Saquear mejoras[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Las unidades militares pueden destruir las mejoras que haya en un territorio neutral o en el de una civilización con la que estés en guerra. Para ello, mueve la unidad hasta la mejora objetivo y haz clic en el botón "Saquear" (esto consumirá uno de los puntos de movimiento de la unidad). Puede que incluso consigas un botín por tu acto de vandalismo. Si hay varias mejoras en una casilla (una carretera y una mina, por ejemplo) la unidad destruirá una de ellas cada turno. Ten en cuenta que a los [LINK=CONCEPT_BARBARIANS]bárbaros[\LINK] nómadas les encantará saquear tus mejoras si tienen la oportunidad.

TEXT.English: by Moctezuma[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Military units affect surroundings via combat influence.[PARAGRAPH:2]After each combat between two units: some amount of culture accumulated in each square of combat area is transferred from loser player/AI to winner player/AI. Combat area (i.e. influence radius) is: attacker plot, defended plot and near surrounding plots (see definition of influence radius bellow). Note: This way I try to simulate effect of battle victory: some peoples have tendency to give up and flip to victorious side.[PARAGRAPH:2]Rules: [ICON_BULLET] It works for both field battle and city assault. [ICON_BULLET] It works for both attacking and defending. [ICON_BULLET] If last defending unit in city dies: combat influence is increased greatly (an emergency militia may be "auto-drafted", check new resistance rules later). [ICON_BULLET] If victorious unit has warlord: combat influence is increased. [ICON_BULLET] If attacking unit withdraws: no culture transfer happens. [ICON_BULLET] Calculated culture exchange cannot be higher than loser's remaining culture in plot. This means that no culture transfer happens in empty neutral territory: nobody is living there to be influenced. In third-party territory a culture transfer occurs only if some loser's culture is accumulated there. [ICON_BULLET] It works also for attacking/defending barbarians in player or barbarian territory (this can be disabled via XML file). [ICON_BULLET] Also water squares are affected by combat influence. [ICON_BULLET] Naval combats use same influence rules as land combats. Note: if naval battle occurs near land, also land squares are affected (naval influence can be disabled via XML file). [ICON_BULLET] No culture is exchanged during city bombardment (via catapults, ships, bombers, ICBM); during fighter interception; or if worker/settler is captured out of city. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Active city resistance[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If last defending unit in the city dies and city resistance is sufficient then one militia unit emerges in city, otherwise it is captured just like in vanilla. Resistance is sufficient if defender's culture in central plot is same or higher than attacker's culture in central plot (culture ratios in central city plot you can check also in the city screen). Note: This new rule tries to simulate active people resistance in highly cultured cities. Militia unit is "auto-drafted": [ICON_BULLET] Best available regular unit type is selected using same rules as for standard drafting: i.e. warrior, axeman, maceman, musketman, rifleman... [ICON_BULLET] Auto-drafted unit begins with 25% health (configurable in XML). This represents very low training level of quickly gathered militia. [ICON_BULLET] Draft anger is 50% of standard draft anger: high danger means low anger. (configurable in XML) [ICON_BULLET] City population is reduced by 1 (it doesn't depend on unit type). [ICON_BULLET] Auto-draft is not limited like standard draft: new militia unit is "auto-drafted" when previous one dies and resistance is still sufficient. [ICON_BULLET] When city population is reduced to 1, the city is captured even if resistance is still sufficient. [ICON_BULLET] There is no technology requirement for auto-draft: this is not real conscription: imagine peoples that are just trying in defend their homes. [ICON_BULLET] It takes some time to accumulate sufficient culture: if city is attacked early no militia emerges. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pillage influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When enemy unit pillages tile improvement, some amount of accumulated culture is transferred from improvement owner to unit owner. Only single square is affected.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: This rule was added to provide incentive for defender to defend own territory and not only stay inside cities. It reflects situation where farmers, miners or villagers escape due to farm, mine or village is burned down by invader.[PARAGRAPH:2]This rule is optional and can be disabled via XML. Rules: [ICON_BULLET] It works only in enemy territory (no influence in friendly or neutral territory) [ICON_BULLET] No influence form route pillage (roads, railroads). [ICON_BULLET] Works also for sea improvements (e.g. fishing boats). [ICON_BULLET] For improvements like towns, each downgrade influences given square. [PARAGRAPH:2][H1]Gameplay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Player is informed about effects of IDW this way:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]After each battle a number with influence % (i.e. exchanged culture ratio) is shown in the game log. It is calculated in defended plot only, but whole combat area is influenced. Reason that I'm using defended plot here is because it is in most cases the most important one (e.g. central city square). [ICON_BULLET] Green color means culture increase for you [ICON_BULLET] Red color means culture decrease for you. [PARAGRAPH:2]When last city defender dies and militia unit is "auto-drafted", a remaining resistance % is shown in the game log.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Result of changes on gameplay:[\BOLD] [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]1. More dynamic borders during wars:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In vanilla game a culture plays significant role only in the beginning. In later stages the borders are almost fixed: big changes happen only if cities are captured.[PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules you can fight for territory between cities and not only for cities itself. I think that this "frontline" effect really improves gameplay. You can "win" quite large area with several resources even without conquering single enemy city! Possible tactics if you don't have sufficient power to conquer cities could be stay/pillage/heal near your borders and influence squares by killing approaching enemies. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]2. Surprise or backstabbing attacks are less effective:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Attacked city can for short time defend itself even if last defender dies if resistance is sufficient: this increases reaction time for defending player if he has many units in the opposite side of empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]However you cannot count on auto-drafted units. These are meant only to slow-down attack in case when everything else fails. In most cases a militia units can defend high cultured city only 1-2 turns until real defender units arrive because: [ICON_BULLET] Militia unit begins with very low health, so if it is attacked in same turn, it almost certainly dies. [ICON_BULLET] City resistance decreases very quickly because victory influence is much higher when last city defender dies (see NoCityDefenderMultiplier). [ICON_BULLET] Each auto-drafted unit increases unhappiness in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: I cannot make militia units more effective, because then player can abuse it: e.g. move out all defenders from city and later counterattack damaged attackers. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]3. High cultured cities are harder to conquer (more militia formed) but easier to hold after capture [\BOLD]because city's central square has quite good amount of conqueror's culture immediately after capture.[PARAGRAPH:2]This means:[PARAGRAPH:2]No problem with cultural flipping of captured city back to original owner: In vanilla is this problem is fixed by disabling startup option: "City flipping after conquest". This is no longer needed in this mod.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much smaller problem with cultural flipping of captured city to neighbor civ, which can be in peace with conqueror. Naturally, if just conquered city has been in big cultural pressure prior to capture it will be in pressure also after it, because culture is transferred only from city's previous owner.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: culture buildings in newly captured city are still very important because city still begins with zero culture (only plots are influenced by combat). [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]4. No problems with stealing of conquered city:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This happens often in multiplayer with simultaneous turns but sometimes it occurs also in single-player: Two players are doing joint attack on same enemy city; first player destroys all defenders; second one just waits until last defender remains there and then attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the city capture is fairer: culture in central city square is increased after each victory for each attacking player separately. If no defender unit is left then attacker, whose culture in central square is higher than owners culture, captures the city. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]5. In battles quality counts more than quantity:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the conquest is easier with smaller stack of high strength units than with bigger stack of low strength units: Veteran unit makes more influence (see UnitExperienceMultiplier) and better victory/loss ratio means more culture transferred to attacker. Some examples: [ICON_BULLET] Suicide catapults are little less effective: due to losses, defender's culture increases more often. [ICON_BULLET] Blitz units like tanks are very effective: due to multiple culture exchanges per turn. This really speeds up the conquest of very highly cultured cities in later stages of game, which can be really slow otherwise. [ICON_BULLET] Warlord units are more effective than normal units (see WarlordMultiplier).
TEXT.French: par Moctezuma[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Les Combats affectent la culture des cases sur lesquelles ils se déroulent: un certain pourcentage de culture du Vainqueur est transféré sur la case, aux dépends de la culture du vaincu.

TEXT.English: [H1]Inquisition[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]While the missionary seeks to spread the state religion, the Inquisitor is used to remove all non-state religions from a city. Like the Missionary, the inquisitor is limited to a maximum of only 3 units a player can have at any one time. As the defender of the official state religious faith, the inquisitor is a very powerful unit. If an inquisition is successful, all non-state religions and their associated non-state religious buildings will be removed from the city. Whether the inquisition is successful or not, the unit is used up after executing an inquisition. Thus, the production of many inquisitors may be necessary to finally achieve religious unity.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Foreign Inquisitions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You can also conduct a foreign inquisition, if you meet all 3 prerequisites below.[PARAGRAPH:2]To build an inquisitor: You must have researched Fundamantalism, have a state religion in the city and have Intolerant religion civic active.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a city: You must have your state religion previously established in a city and there must be at least one non-state religion established in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a foreign city: The foreign civilization must have the same state religion as you, the foreign civilization must have an open borders agreement with you and the foreign city must also meet the requirements of prerequisite 2 above.[PARAGRAPH:2]If you want to play a game with Limited Religions, then simply enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Respawn Holy Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Respawn a Holy City that was purged by an inquisitor or razed during wars. By default this feature is off but you can enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Purging Holy Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This game feature allows Inquisitors to purge Holy Cities which means that if the city has non-state religion Holy City and you purge the city with Inquisitor the non-state religious holy city is removed. This feature is off by default. If you want to use this feature you can enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).
TEXT.French: [H1]Inquisition[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Alors que les Missionnaires cherchent à propager la religion d'Etat, l'Inquisiteur est utilisé pour éradiquer les religions non officielles d'une Ville.

TEXT.English: Player cities can now expand to a third level radius, if enabled. After a city reaches an "Influential" level of culture, it's third ring of tiles will become workable, allowing for mega-cities to emerge. Players can use this expanded access to food to fuel thier specialist economy, drive their war machine, or to gain access to prevously locked resources. However, because the third ring of culture is now workable, this change makes maintaining your cultural borders more important. Losing access to some outer-ring mines may become the difference to defeat or failure in a war. In addition, players will face other new challenges. Because cities will reach much higher levels of population before running out of food, unhealthy and unhappy cities may become problematic. If poorly maintained, these larger cities may even decide to revel against your leadership. Players should spend extra effort to keep these mega-cities healthy and happy.
TEXT.French: Les Villes peuvent avec cette option s'étendre sur un troisième niveau. Lorsque la Ville a atteint le niveau culturel "Influent", ce troisième cercle devient disponible et exploitable, permettant l'émergence de véritables mégapoles, permettant un meilleur approvisionnement en nourriture, un accès à des ressources supplémentaires... Cependant, cela change donc l'importance des frontières culturelles que vous devrez maintenir plus étendues que jamais. De plus, les Villes atteignant des niveaux de population plus élevés, les conditions sanitaires et le bonheur pourront devenir plus problématique.
TEXT.German: Wenn diese Modifikation aktiviert ist, können Städte ihr Einzugsgebiet noch weiter ausdehnen. Wenn eine Stadt eine "einflussreiche" Kulturstufe erreicht, wird der dritte Ring von Feldern im Umkreis zur Bearbeitung freigeschaltet, wodurch wahre Megastädte entstehen können. Der zusätzliche Radius kann genutzt werden, um die Wirtschaft anzukurbeln, die Kriegsmaschinerie am Laufen zu halten oder um Zugang zu bisher nicht erreichbaren Ressourcen zu erhalten. Da der dritte Ring nun bearbeitet werden kann, sollten die Grenzen ganz besonders gut geschützt werden. Den Zugriff auf eine der äußeren Minen zu verlieren, kann im schlimmsten Fall kriegsentscheidende Bedeutung haben. Mit der neuen Größe kommen natürlich auch neue Probleme auf den Spieler zu. Weil Städte jetzt viel weiter anwachsen können, bevor die Nahrungsmittel ausgehen, können Krankheiten und Unzufriedenheit zum Problem werden. Wenn sie schlecht verwaltet werden, können sich diese Städte sogar dazu entschließen, gegen die bestehende Herrschaft zu revoltieren. Die Spieler sollten also peinlichst darauf achten, die neuen Megastädte glücklich und gesund zu halten.
TEXT.Italian: Le città possono ora espandersi in un raggio di tre caselle, se quest'opzione è attivata. Dopo CHE una città raggiunge un livello di cultura "influente", il terzo anello di caselle sarà lavorabile, consentendo alle mega-città di emergere. I giocatori possono usare questo accesso allargato al cibo per rifornire la loro economia basata sugli specialisti, guidare la loro macchina da guerra, o per ottenere l'accesso alle risorse prima bloccate. Tuttavia, poiché il terzo anello della cultura è adesso praticabile, questa modifica rende la manutenzione dei confini culturali più importante. Perdere l'accesso ad alcune miniere nell'anello esterno può diventare la differenza per la vittoria o il fallimento in una guerra. Inoltre, i giocatori si troveranno ad affrontare altre sfide nuove. Poichè le città raggiungeranno livelli molto più alti di popolazione saranno prima a corto di cibo; le città malsane e infelici possono diventare problematiche. Se mal gestite, queste città più grandi possono anche decidere di rivoltarsi contro il proprio possessore. I giocatori dovrebbero spendere ulteriori sforzi per mantenere queste mega-città sane e felici.
Città più grandi
Avvio avanzato

TEXT.English: Each civilization in Civilization IV has one or two leaders available to lead it. When you start a game of Civ, you will pick which civilization you want to lead; if that civilization has two available leaders, you pick them which of them you want to play. Each computer-controlled civilization has a leader as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader Personalities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When you control a leader, you determine how your leader interacts with the world around him or her. Is the leader honest or shifty? Is the leader open, or paranoid? Is the leader aggressive or peaceful? It's up to you. When the computer controls a leader, the computer determines the leader's behavior. Often, the leader behaves like his or her historical counterparts - but don't count on it. Gandhi will USUALLY be peaceful and friendly, but he may from time to time turn out to be a warmongering backstabber. You have been warned!.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leaders and Diplomacy[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A leader's personality and his or her interpretation of the current game situation will determine how the leader negotiates with you. Further, leaders have long memories; if you deal fairly with them, they'll remember it. And if you betray them, they'll remember that, as well. Check out [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for more information on this topic.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader Traits[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Leaders in Civilization have "traits" which help determine the kind of civilization they are best at running. Each leader has two of the following traits:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggressive[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Free "Combat I" [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotion[\LINK] for melee and gunpowder units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Creative[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] per city per turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Expansive[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]Health Points[\LINK] per city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Financial[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]Commerce[\LINK] on any squares which normally produce two or more commerce.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Industrious[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]Wonder[\LINK] production.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organized[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civic Upkeep[\LINK] cost.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Philosophical[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100%% [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person[\LINK] birth rate.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Spiritual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]No anarchy from changing civics.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each trait also allows civilizations that possess it to construct some buildings at double speed; for example, leaders with the Philosophical trait build [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]Universities[\LINK] twice as fast.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader List[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Check out the [LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]Leader List[\LINK] for a complete list of the leaders in Civilization IV, their game traits, and historical backgrounds.
TEXT.French: Chaque civilisation de Civilization IV dispose d'un ou deux héros. Lorsque vous lancez une partie, vous choisissez la civilisation que vous voulez jouer, et si celle-ci a deux héros possibles, vous pouvez choisir celui que vous voulez incarner. Les civilisations contrôlées par l'ordinateur ont aussi un héros.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Personnalité du héros[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Lorsque vous contrôlez un héros, vous déterminez ses réactions par rapport au monde qui l'entoure. Est-il honnête ou sournois? Ouvert ou paranoïaque? Agressif ou pacifique? A vous de décider. De la même manière, l'ordinateur détermine le comportement des héros qu'il contrôle. Généralement, un héros se comporte comme le personnage historique qu'il représente, mais ne comptez pas trop là-dessus. Gandhi sera a priori pacifique et amical, mais il peut de temps à autres se transformer en belliciste accompli. Vous voilà prévenu![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Héros et diplomatie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La personnalité du héros et sa vision de la situation déterminent sa façon de négocier avec vous. En outre, les héros ont une mémoire d'éléphant: respectez vos engagements et ils s'en souviendront. Trahissez-les, et ils s'en souviendront aussi. Pour plus d'informations sur le sujet, consultez la section [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomatie[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Caractère des héros[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les "traits de caractère" des héros permettent de déterminer le type de civilisations qu'ils sont le plus à même de diriger. Chaque héros a deux des traits suivants:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Agressif[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotions[\LINK] "Combat I" gratuites pour les unités de combat rapproché ou munies d'armes à feu.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Créatif[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]points de culture[\LINK] par ville et par tour.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Expansif[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]points de santé[\LINK] par ville.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Financier[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]commerce[\LINK] par case produisant au moins deux commerces habituellement.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Industrieux[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50 %% pour la construction de [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]merveilles[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organisé[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-5 pour le coût [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]d'entretien du régime[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Philosophe[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100 %% de [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]personnages illustres[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Spirituel[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Pas d'anarchie lors des changements de régimes.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chacun de ces traits de caractère permet aussi de construire deux types de bâtiments deux fois plus vite. Les héros philosophes, par exemple, peuvent construire des [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]bibliothèques[\LINK] et des [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]universités[\LINK] deux fois plus vite.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Liste des héros[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Pour voir la liste complète des héros de Civilization IV, ainsi que leurs traits de caractères et leur origine historique, consultez la [LINK=LEADER_LIST]liste des héros[\LINK].
TEXT.German: Alle Zivilisationen werden von einem Oberhaupt geleitet. Am Anfang des Spiels müssen Sie sich für eine Zivilisation entscheiden. Stehen für diese Zivilisation mehrere Oberhäupter zur Verfügung, dürfen Sie sich eines aussuchen. Auch computergesteuerte Zivilisationen haben Oberhäupter.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Persönlichkeit des Oberhaupts[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Wenn Sie ein Oberhaupt steuern, bestimmen Sie dessen Charakter. Ist Ihr Oberhaupt ehrlich, verschlagen, offen, paranoid, aggressiv oder friedliebend? Sie haben die Wahl. Steuert der Computer ein Oberhaupt, bestimmt er dessen Verhalten. In der Regel verhalten sich Oberhäupter wie ihre historischen Vorbilder. Allerdings sollten Sie sich darauf lieber nicht verlassen. Gandhi ist NORMALERWEISE ein friedlicher und freundlicher Mann. Allerdings kann auch er sich unter bestimmten Umständen in einen blutrünstigen Kriegsherrn verwandeln. Sagen Sie später also nicht, sie seien nicht gewarnt worden.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Oberhäupter und Diplomatie[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Persönlichkeit eines Oberhaupts und seine Einschätzung der Spielsituation bestimmt seine Verhandlungsstrategie. Darüber hinaus haben Oberhäupter ein gutes Gedächtnis. Überlegen Sie es sich also gut, ob Sie einem Oberhaupt ohne nennenswerten Grund vor den Kopf stoßen. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [\LINK][CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomatie[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Eigenschaften der Oberhäupter[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Oberhäupter des Spiels haben bestimmte Eigenschaften. Diese bestimmen wiederum die Wahl einer geeigneten Zivilisation. Jedes Oberhaupt hat zwei der folgenden Eigenschaften:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggressiv[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Kostenlose "Kampf 1"-[LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Beförderung[\LINK] für Nahkampf- und Feuerwaffeneinheiten.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Kreativ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Kultur[\LINK] pro Stadt und Runde.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Expansionistisch[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]Gesundheitspunkte[\LINK] pro Stadt.[BOLD]Wirtschaftlich[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]Wirtschaft[\LINK] für Geländefelder, die normalerweise zwei oder mehr Wirtschaftseinheiten produzieren.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Industriell[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50%% auf den Bau von [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]Wundern[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organisiert[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Gesellschaftsformenkosten[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Philosophisch[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100%% Geburtenrate [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Großer Persönlichkeiten[\LINK].[BOLD]Spirituell[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Keine Unruhen beim Wechsel der Gesellschaftsform.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jede Eigenschaft ermöglicht der jeweiligen Zivilisation den Bau von einigen Gebäudem mit doppelter Geschwindigkeit. Philosophische Oberhäupter können beispielsweise doppelt so schnell [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]Universitäten[\LINK] bauen.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Oberhäupter-Liste[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die [LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]Oberhäupter-Liste[\LINK] enthält alle verfügbaren Oberhäupter, deren Eigenschaften und ihren historischen Hintergrund.
TEXT.Italian: In Civilization IV, ogni civiltà dispone di uno o due leader che possono guidarla. Quando inizi una partita di Civilization, dovrai scegliere quale civiltà guidare: se la civiltà che hai selezionato dispone di due leader, dovrai scegliere con quale giocare. Anche le civiltà controllate dal computer hanno un leader.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Personalità dei leader[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Quando controlli un leader, decidi anche come il tuo leader può interagire con il mondo che lo/la circonda. Sarà onesto o ambiguo? Sarà di aperte vedute, o paranoico? Aggressivo o pacifico? Dipende solo da te. Quando è il computer a controllare un leader, è lui a stabilirne il comportamento. Spesso, il leader controllato dal computer tende a comportarsi come la sua controparte storica - ma non ci contare troppo. Gandhi sarà SOLITAMENTE pacifico e amichevole, ma potrebbe sporadicamente trasformarsi in un traditore guerrafondaio. Sei stato avvertito![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader e diplomazia[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La personalità di un leader e la sua interpretazione della situazione di gioco determinano il modo in cui negozierà con te. Inoltre, i leader hanno buona memoria: se tratti correttamente con loro, se lo ricorderanno. E se li tradisci, stai certo che non se lo dimenticheranno mai. Leggi la sezione relativa alla [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomazia[\LINK] per avere maggiori dettagli sull'argomento.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Punti di forza dei leader[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]I leader presenti in Civilization IV hanno dei "punti di forza" che aiutano a capire quale tipo di civiltà sono più adatti a guidare. Ogni leader possiede due dei seguenti punti di forza:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggressivo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Assegna la [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]promozione[\LINK] "Combattimento I" a tutte le unità da combattimento ravvicinato e unità con armi da fuoco.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Creativo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 in [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]cultura[\LINK] per ogni città, per ogni turno.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Espansionista[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 in [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]punti salute[\LINK] per ogni città.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Commerciale[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 nel [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]commercio[\LINK] in qualsiasi area in cui normalmente vengono prodotte due o più unità di commercio.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Industrioso[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50%% per la produzione delle [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]Meraviglie[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organizzato[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]costo di mantenimento[\LINK] del governo locale.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Filosofico[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100%% per il tasso di natalità dei [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Grandi Personaggi[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Spirituale[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Nessuna anarchia in seguito al cambio di governo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ogni tratto consente inoltre alla civiltà che lo possiede di costruire alcuni edifici a velocità doppia rispetto al solito: ad esempio, un leader con tratto Filosofico può costruire [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]università[\LINK] in metà del tempo.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Elenco dei leader[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Controlla l'[LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]elenco dei leader[\LINK] per una lista completa dei leader presenti in Civilization IV, le loro caratteristiche di gioco, e alcune informazioni di stampo storico.
TEXT.Spanish: En Civilization IV, cada civilización cuenta con uno o dos líderes disponibles para que la guíen. Cuando empieces una partida, escogerás la civilización que quieras llevar y, si ésta cuenta con dos líderes, tendrás que elegir también a cuál quieres encarnar. Cada civilización que lleve el ordenador también tendrá un solo líder.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Personalidad de los líderes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Cuando llevas a un líder, eres tú quien decide cómo se relaciona con el mundo que le rodea. ¿Es honrado o artero? ¿Abierto o paranoico? ¿Agresivo o pacífico? Queda en tus manos. Cuando el ordenador lleva a un líder, es éste quien decide el comportamiento del mismo. El líder suele comportarse como su homónimo histórico, pero no siempre ha de ser así. Gandhi será pacífico y amistoso NORMALMENTE pero, de vez en cuando, puede que se convierta en un traidor belicoso. Te hemos avisado.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Líderes y diplomacia[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]La personalidad de un líder y su interpretación de lo que esté ocurriendo en el mundo determinarán cómo negociará contigo. Además, los líderes tienen buena memoria: si te portas bien con ellos, lo recordarán. Si les traicionas, también lo recordarán. Repasa la [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diplomacia[\LINK] para obtener más información sobre este tema.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Rasgos de los líderes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]En Civilization, los líderes tienen "rasgos" que ayudan a determinar qué civilización es más conveniente que dirijan. Cada líder tiene dos de los rasgos siguientes:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Agresivo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Un [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]ascenso[\LINK] gratis de "Combate I" para las unidades de cuerpo a cuerpo y con armas de pólvora.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Creativo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 a la [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]cultura[\LINK] de cada ciudad por turno.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Comunicativo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 a los [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]puntos de salud[\LINK] de cada ciudad.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Financiero[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 al [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]comercio[\LINK] en todas las casillas que normalmente producirían dos o más de comercio.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diligente[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50%% a la producción de [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]maravillas[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organizado[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50%% al coste de [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]mantenimiento de los principios[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Filosófico[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100%% a la tasa de natalidad de [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]grandes personajes[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Espiritual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]No habrá anarquía por cambiar de principios.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cada rasgo también permite al líder que lo tenga construir algunos edificios en su civilización al doble de velocidad. Por ejemplo, los líderes con el rasgo de Filosófico construyen [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]universidades[\LINK] el doble de rápido.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lista de líderes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Revisa la [LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]lista de líderes[\LINK] para tener una visión completa de los líderes de Civilization IV, sus rasgos y trasfondos históricos.

TEXT.English: As a civilization grows, it requires an ever-larger infrastructure to support it. Entire new layers of bureaucrats appear to handle the increasingly complex business of empire. And with every new layer of bureaucracy comes new inefficiencies, as well as increased opportunities for corruption. In Civilization IV, this is reflected in your civilization's "city maintenance cost."[PARAGRAPH:2]Two factors determine a civilization's basic city maintenance cost: the number of cities you possess, and the distance of individual cites from a seat of government.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Number of Cities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As you add cities to your civilization, the cost of managing EVERY city increases. Thus, as your civilization grows, adding new cities will quickly drive up your city maintenance costs. For instance, let's assume that the first city costs one gold to manage, and every new city increases the cost of managing your cities by one. So you pay one gold in management expenses when you have one city. When you build another city, you are now paying two gold PER city, so your overall costs goes up to four. Adding a third city will increase your maintenance costs to nine, and so on. (Note that these numbers are for example only; the actual formula for determining maintenance is more complex.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Distance from Seat of Government[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city's maintenance cost is also affected by its distance from a "seat of government." At game start the [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palace[\LINK], which appears automatically in the first city you build, is your seat of government. Cities farther away from the palace are more expensive to maintain than closer cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lowering Maintenance Costs[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Courthouses[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Building a [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]Courthouse[\LINK] cuts a city's maintenance cost in half. Courthouses are also required to build the Forbidden Palace national wonder (see below). If your civ finds itself choking under high maintenance costs from expanding too far afield, make sure to build courthouses as quickly as possible.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Move Your Palace[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If your palace is out on the edge of your civilization, you can construct it in a more centralized position. Warning: the original palace disappears when the new one appears.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Add Seats of Government[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Two wonders, the [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Forbidden Palace[\LINK] and [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles,[\LINK] act as additional seats of government. Cities pay maintenance based upon their distance to the NEAREST seat of government, so spreading these about your empire will do wonders for lowering your maintenance costs. Although the Forbidden Palace is a [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]National Wonder[\LINK] and always available to your civ, be aware that only one civilization in the world will be able to construct Versailles.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]State Property[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]State Property[\LINK] civic removes all distance-based maintenance costs.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Make More Money![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can, of course, counter the rising costs of city maintenance by simply making more money. See [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Wealth[\LINK] for further suggestions.
TEXT.French: Au fur et à mesure qu'elle s'étend, une civilisation a besoin d'infrastructures de plus en plus importantes. De nouvelles couches de bureaucrates se superposent pour gérer l'empire de plus en plus complexe. Et à chaque couche supplémentaire s'ajoutent de nouveaux problèmes d'incompétence et de corruption. Dans Civilization IV, cela apparaît dans votre "coût d'entretien des villes."[PARAGRAPH:2]Deux facteurs déterminent le coût d'entretien de base des villes d'une civilisation: le nombre de villes que vous possédez et la distance qui les sépare du siège du gouvernement.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Nombre de villes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Au fur et à mesure que vous ajoutez des villes à votre civilisation, le coût d'entretien de CHAQUE ville augmente, le coût total a donc une croissance exponentielle. Par exemple, imaginons que la première ville coûte un or à gérer, et que chaque nouvelle ville augmente ce coût de un. Vous payez un or tant que vous possédez une ville. Fondez une ville, et vous paierez deux or par ville, soit quatre au total. Ajoutez une troisième ville, et le coût d'entretien passe à neuf, etc. (remarque: ces chiffres n'ont qu'une valeur d'exemple. La formule qui détermine le coût d'entretien est plus complexe).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Distance avec le siège du gouvernement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le coût d'entretien d'une ville dépend aussi de la distance qui la sépare du "siège du gouvernement". Au début de la partie, le siège du gouvernement est le [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]palais[\LINK], qui apparaît automatiquement dans la première de vos villes. Les villes éloignées du palais coûtent plus cher à entretenir que les villes les plus proches.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Diminuer le coût d'entretien[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Tribunaux[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Le fait de construire un [LINK=COURTHOUSE]tribunal[\LINK] divise par deux le coût d'entretien d'une ville. Les tribunaux sont aussi nécessaires pour bâtir la merveille Palais interdit (voir plus bas). Si vous avez du mal à gérer le coût d'entretien des villes, veillez à construire des tribunaux le plus rapidement possible.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Déplacer le palais[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Si votre palais est excentré, vous pouvez en construire un nouveau dans une ville plus centrale. Attention: l'ancien palais disparaît dès que le nouveau apparaît.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ajouter des sièges du gouvernement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Deux merveilles, le [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Palais interdit[\LINK] et [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles[\LINK], agissent comme des sièges du gouvernement supplémentaires. Le coût d'entretien des villes est fixé selon la distance qui les sépare du siège le plus proche, n'hésitez pas à bâtir ces merveilles le plus loin possible du palais pour réduire le coût d'entretien des villes. Si le Palais interdit est une [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]merveille nationale[\LINK] et reste donc toujours disponible pour votre civilisation, sachez qu'une seule civilisation peut construire Versailles.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Nationalisation[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Le régime de la [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]nationalisation[\LINK] supprime le coût d'entretien lié à l'éloignement.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Gagner plus d'or![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez, bien sûr, compenser l'augmentation des coûts d'entretien des villes en gagnant plus d'or. Pour plus de détails, consultez la section [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Richesse[\LINK].
TEXT.German: Je größer eine Zivilisation wird, desto mehr Geld braucht sie für die Instandhaltung ihrer Infrastruktur und den Aufbau eines komplexen Verwaltungsapparats. Zudem sind große Zivilisationen besonders durch Misswirtschaft und Korruption gefährdet. In Civilization IV wirken sich diese Faktoren auf die laufenden Kosten Ihrer Städte aus.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die laufenden Kosten Ihrer Zivilisation werden primär von der Zahl Ihrer Städte und deren Entfernung von Ihrem Regierungssitz beeinflusst.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Zahl der Städte[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Gründen Sie eine neue Stadt, steigen die laufenden Kosten aller Städte. Je größer Ihre Zivilisation wird, desto höher sind also auch ihre laufenden Kosten. Nehmen wir einmal an, die laufenden Kosten Ihrer ersten Stadt betragen 1 Gold pro Runde. Diese Kosten steigen mit jeder neuen Stadt um 1 Gold. Gründen Sie eine zweite Stadt, müssen Sie 2 Gold PRO Stadt (also insgesamt 4 Gold) an laufenden Kosten abführen. Gründen Sie eine dritte Stadt, steigen die laufenden Kosten bereits auf 9 Gold an usw. Diese Zahlen dienen lediglich als Beispiel. Die tatsächliche Berechnung der laufenden Kosten ist deutlich komplexer.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Räumliche Entfernung vom Regierungssitz[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die laufenden Kosten einer Stadt werden von ihrer Entfernung zum Regierungssitz nachhaltig beeinflusst. Am Anfang des Spiels wird in Ihrer ersten Stadt automatisch ein [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palast[\LINK] (Ihr Regierungssitz) errichtet. Weit vom Palast entfernte Städte haben höhere laufende Kosten als Städte in seiner Nähe.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Senkung der laufenden Kosten[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Gerichtsgebäude[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Bauen Sie ein [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]Gerichtsgebäude[\LINK], um die laufenden Kosten einer Stadt zu halbieren. Darüber hinaus sind Gerichtsgebäude die Voraussetzung für den Bau des Nationalwunders "Verbotene Stadt" (siehe unten). Leidet Ihre Zivilisation aufgrund einer allzu schnellen Expansion unter hohen laufenden Kosten, sollten Sie schnellstmöglich ein Gerichtsgebäude bauen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Verlegen Sie Ihren Palast[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Steht Ihr Palast an der Grenze Ihrer Zivilisation, können Sie Ihren Regierungssitz in eine günstiger gelegene Stadt verlegen. Warnung: Der erste Palast geht hierdurch verloren.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Regierungssitze hinzufügen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Zwei Wunder ([LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Verbotene Stadt[\LINK] und [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles[\LINK]) dienen als zusätzliche Regierungssitze. Nach ihrem Bau sind die laufenden Kosten einer Stadt von ihrer Entfernung zum nächstgelegenen Regierungssitz abhängig. Wenn Sie diese also klug platzieren, können Sie Ihre laufenden Kosten deutlich senken. Die Verbotene Stadt steht als [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Nationalwunder[\LINK] allen Zivilisationen zur Verfügung. Versailles kann als Weltwunder nur von einer Zivilisation gebaut werden.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Staatsbesitz[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Die Gesellschaftsform [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]Planwirtschaft[\LINK] hebt alle entfernungsanhängigen Mehrkosten auf.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wirtschaftswachstum[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Sie können den ansteigenden laufenden Kosten auch entgegenwirken, indem Sie mehr Gold erwirtschaften. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Reichtum[\LINK].
TEXT.Italian: Man mano che una civiltà cresce, aumentano anche le sue richieste di infrastrutture che la mantengano. Appariranno così intere legioni di burocrati che si prenderanno cura della complessità crescente di un impero in espansione. Come sappiamo, insieme a un nuovo livello di burocrazia arrivano nuove inefficienze e nuove opportunità di corruzione. In Civilization IV, tutto questo si riflette nel "costo di mantenimento della città".[PARAGRAPH:2]Due sono i fattori primari che determinano tale costo: il numero di città in tuo possesso, e la distanza di ogni singola città dalla sede di governo.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Numero di città[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Con l'aumentare del numero di città della tua civiltà, aumenterà anche il costo di gestione di OGNI città. Di conseguenza, con l'espansione della tua civiltà, l'aggiunta di nuovi agglomerati urbani farà salire rapidamente i loro costi di mantenimento. Ad esempio, supponiamo che la prima città abbia un costo di mantenimento pari a un oro, e che ogni nuova città aumenti tale costo di uno. Questo vuol dire che all'inizio, quando hai una sola città, paghi un solo oro per la sua gestione; quando ne costruisci un'altra, pagherai due ori PER ciascuna città, per un totale di quattro. Costruendo la terza, il costo lieviterà a nove, e così via. Tieni presente che questi sono solo esempi: la formula che calcola esattamente i costi di mantenimento è molto più complessa.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Distanza dalla sede del governo[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Il costo di mantenimento di una città è influenzato anche dalla sua distanza dalla "sede del governo". All'inizio della partita, la sede del tuo governo si trova nel [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]palazzo[\LINK], che appare automaticamente nella prima città che costruisci. Le città più lontane sono più costose da mantenere di quelle più vicine.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ridurre i costi di mantenimento[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Palazzo di giustizia[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Costruire un [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]palazzo di giustizia[\LINK] dimezza i costi di mantenimento; sono richiesti anche per costruire la Meraviglia del Palazzo Proibito (vedi sotto). Se la tua civiltà sta per soffocare sotto costi di mantenimento troppo elevati causati dall'espansione, assicurati di costruire palazzi di giustizia il più rapidamente possibile.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Sposta il palazzo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Se la sede del governo si trova ai confini della tua civiltà, puoi costruirla in posizione più centralizzata. Il palazzo originale sparirà una volta costruito quello nuovo.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggiunta di sedi del governo[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Due Meraviglie, il [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Palazzo Proibito[\LINK] e [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles[\LINK] possono servire come sedi di governo supplementari; le città pagano i loro costi di mantenimento sulla base della PIÚ VICINA sede di governo, quindi aggiungerle nelle città dell'impero farà letteralmente "Meraviglie" per abbassare i costi di mantenimento. Sebbene il Palazzo Proibito sia una [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Meraviglia Nazionale[\LINK] sempre disponibile per la tua civiltà, ricordati che solo una civiltà al mondo sarà in grado di costruire Versailles.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Proprietà statale[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]La forma di governo [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]Proprietà statale[\LINK] annulla tutti i costi di mantenimento legati alla distanza.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Guadagna più denaro![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Puoi, ovviamente, controbilanciare i maggiori costi di mantenimento semplicemente guadagnando più denaro. Vedi la voce [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]ricchezza[\LINK] per qualche suggerimento in tal senso.
TEXT.Spanish: A medida que una civilización crece, necesita una infraestructura cada vez mayor para sostenerla. Nuevos estratos completos de burócratas aparecerán para gestionar la creciente complejidad financiera del imperio. Y, con cada estrato de burocracia, habrá más incompetencia y mayores oportunidades de corrupción. En Civilization IV, esto se refleja en el "coste de mantenimiento por ciudad" de la civilización.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dos factores determinan el coste de mantenimiento básico de una ciudad: la cantidad de ciudades que tengas y la distancia que las separe de la sede de gobierno.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cantidad de ciudades[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A medida que añadas ciudades a la civilización, aumentará el coste de mantenimiento de CADA ciudad. Así, a medida que crezca la civilización al añadirse nuevas ciudades, los costes de mantenimiento de éstas aumentarán rápidamente. Por ejemplo, supongamos que gestionar la primera ciudad te cuesta uno de oro y que cada nueva ciudad que construyas aumenta el coste de gestión en uno. Pagarás uno de oro por gastos de gestión cuando tengas una ciudad. Cuando construyas otra, pasarás a pagar dos POR ciudad, con lo que los costes totales ascenderán a cuatro. Añadir una tercera ciudad aumentará los costes de mantenimiento a nueve y así sucesivamente (ten en cuenta que estas cifras son solo un ejemplo, la verdadera fórmula para calcular el mantenimiento es bastante más compleja).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Distancia a la sede de gobierno[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]El coste de mantenimiento de una ciudad también se ve afectado por la distancia que la separe de la "sede de gobierno". Cuando empiece la partida, aparecerá un [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]palacio[\LINK], automáticamente en la primera ciudad que construyas: ésa será la sede de tu gobierno. Las ciudades que están más lejos del palacio son más caras de mantener que las que están más cerca.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cómo reducir los costes de mantenimiento[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Delegaciones[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Construir una [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]delegación[\LINK] reduce a la mitad el coste de mantenimiento de una ciudad. Las delegaciones también son necesarias para construir la maravilla nacional de la Ciudad Prohibida (ver más adelante). Si tu civilización se está asfixiando por los elevados costes de mantenimiento que acarrea expandirse demasiado lejos, asegúrate de construir delegaciones en cuanto puedas.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Trasladar el palacio[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Si tienes el palacio en un extremo de tu civilización, puedes construirlo en un lugar más céntrico. Aviso: El palacio original desaparecerá cuando aparezca el nuevo.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Añadir sedes de gobierno[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Dos maravillas, la [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Ciudad Prohibida[\LINK] y [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versalles[\LINK], funcionan como sedes de gobierno adicionales. Las ciudades pagan el mantenimiento por la distancia a la que estén de la sede de gobierno MÁS CERCANA, así que repartirlas por el imperio obrará "maravillas" a la hora de reducir los costes de mantenimiento. Aunque la Ciudad Prohibida es una [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]maravilla nacional[\LINK] y, por tanto, siempre estará disponible para tu civilización, ten en cuenta que solo una civilización será capaz de construir Versalles.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Propiedad estatal[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]El principio de la [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]propiedad estatal[\LINK] elimina todos los costes de mantenimiento basados en la distancia.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ganar más dinero[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Por supuesto, puedes contrarrestar el aumento de costes de mantenimiento de cada ciudad simplemente ganando más dinero. Ver [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Riqueza[\LINK] para obtener más ideas.

TEXT.English: There are three different kinds of maps in Civilization IV: the main map, the mini map, and game maps. The main map and the mini map are sections of Civ IV's interface; see the manual for details on them. This entry deals specifically with game maps.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Game Maps[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Game maps are maps of portions of the world. You can acquire game maps from friendly villagers, or from other civilizations.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Maps from Villagers[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When one of your units enters a village, the villagers may respond by giving you a map of local territory. When they do so, your main map is updated to display the newly-revealed territory. This territory is "explored" (see [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploration[\LINK] for more details).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Trading Maps[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=TECH_PAPER]Paper[\LINK] technology allows you to trade maps with other civilizations. When a civilization trades you a map, all of the territory that civilization has [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]"Explored"[\LINK] is updated on your main map. When you trade another civilization your map, that civilization learns about all of the territory that you have explored.
TEXT.French: Il y a dans Civilization IV trois sortes de cartes: la carte principale, la mini-carte et les cartes de jeu. La carte principale et la mini-carte sont des sections de l'interface du jeu. Pour plus de détails, consultez le manuel. Cette section concerne spécifiquement les cartes de jeu.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cartes de jeu[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les cartes de jeu montrent des parties du monde. Elles vous sont fournies par des villageois amicaux, ou par d'autres civilisations.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cartes de villageois[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Quand une de vos unités entre dans un village, ses habitants peuvent lui offrir une carte de la région. Votre carte principale est alors mise à jour et affiche les territoires ainsi révélés. Ces territoires sont "explorés" (pour plus de détails, consultez la section [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]exploration[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Echanger des cartes[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]La technologie du [LINK=PAPER]papier[\LINK] vous permet d'échanger des cartes avec les autres civilisations. Quand une civilisation vous fournit ainsi sa carte, tout le territoire qu'elle a [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]"exploré"[\LINK] est ajouté à votre carte. Lorsque vous échangez votre propre carte avec une civilisation, celle-ci découvre tout le territoire que vous avez exploré.
TEXT.German: In Civilization IV gibt es drei verschiedene Karten: die Hauptkarte, die Übersichtskarte und handelbare Karten. Die Hauptkarte und die Übersichtskarte sind Teil der Benutzeroberfläche von Civilization IV. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Handbuch. In diesem Abschnitt geht es nur um die handelbaren Karten.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Handelbare Karten[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Handelbare Karten sind Karten von Teilen der Welt. Sie können sie von freundlichen Dorfbewohnern oder anderen Zivilisationen erwerben.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Karten von Dorfbewohnern[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Betritt eine Ihrer Einheiten ein Eingeborenendorf, erhalten Sie möglicherweise eine Karte der Gegend. In diesem Fall wird Ihre Hauptkarte aktualisiert und zeigt nun auch das neue Gebiet an. Dieses Gebiet ist bereits "erkundet" (siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Erkundung).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Kartenhandel[\H2][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Technologie [LINK=TECH_PAPER]Papier[\LINK] ermöglicht Ihnen den Handel mit Karten. Erhalten Sie eine Karte von einer anderen Zivilisation, werden alle Gebiete, die diese bereits [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]erkundet[\LINK] hat, auf Ihrer Karte aktualisiert. Verkaufen Sie einer anderen Zivilisation eine Karte, erfährt diese alles über die Gebiete, die Sie erkundet haben.
TEXT.Italian: In Civilization IV esistono tre diverse tipologie di mappe: la mappa principale, la mini mappa, e le mappe di gioco. La mappa principale e la mini mappa sono parte dell'interfaccia di gioco di Civilization IV; per maggiori dettagli consulta il manuale. In questo paragrafo ci occupiamo specificamente delle mappe di gioco.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Mappe di gioco[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le mappe di gioco rappresentano porzioni del mondo. Puoi acquistare mappe di gioco da abitanti di paesi vicini o da altre civiltà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mappe dagli abitanti dei villaggi[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Quando una delle tue unità entra in un villaggio, i suoi abitanti possono reagire consegnandoti una mappa del territorio di quella zona. Quando lo fanno, la tua mappa viene aggiornata così da mostrare il territorio nel quale la tua unità è appena entrata. Questo territorio viene visto come "esplorato" (vedi la voce [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]esplorazione[\LINK] per ulteriori dettagli).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Scambio di Mappe[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]La tecnologia [LINK=TECH_PAPER]Carta[\LINK] ti permette di scambiare mappe con altre civiltà; quando una civiltà ti cede una mappa, l'intero territorio di quella civiltà viene visto aggiunto alla tua mappa principale come [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]"esplorato"[\LINK]. Quando sei tu a cedere la tua mappa a un'altra civiltà, anch'essa può vedere tutto il tuo territorio come esplorato.
TEXT.Spanish: En Civilization IV hay tres clases diferentes de mapas: el mapa principal, el minimapa y los mapas de la partida. El mapa principal y el minimapa son partes de la interfaz del juego. Consulta el manual para obtener más detalles sobre ellos. En este artículo nos ocuparemos de los mapas de la partida.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Mapas de la partida[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los mapas de la partida son mapas de partes del mundo. Puede facilitártelos un aldeano amistoso o bien otra civilización.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Mapas de los aldeanos[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Cuando una de tus unidades entra en una aldea, los aldeanos pueden responder dándote un mapa de su territorio. Cuando pase eso, se actualizará el mapa principal para mostrar la zona recién revelada. Dicho territorio se considerará "explorado" (ver [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploración[\LINK] para obtener más detalles).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Intercambiar mapas[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]La tecnología del [LINK=TECH_PAPER]papel[\LINK] te permite intercambiar mapas con otras civilizaciones. Cuando una civilización intercambie un mapa contigo, todo el territorio que haya [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]"explorado"[\LINK] se actualizará en tu mapa principal. Cuando intercambies tu mapa con otra civilización, dicha civilización pasará a conocer todo el territorio que hayas explorado.

TEXT.English: Mastery Victory is a completely different type of victory condition. If enabled, all other victory conditions are ignored. Victory is judged at the end of time, not when a player achieves a particular goal. To win, players must have the most points at the end of the game, and of course, still be alive.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Distribution of Points[\BOLD]: [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per tile of land controlled [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per percentage of population controlled by your team [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per total percentage of world culture controlled by your team [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per percentage of the world religion you control (only the top religion you control is scored) [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per percentage of total power left on the world at the time [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point per percentage of Wonders [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]constructed[COLOR_REVERT] [ICON_BULLET] 30 Points for each city that achieves legendary status [ICON_BULLET] 100 Points to each Civilization that launches a starship.
TEXT.French: La Victoire de Maître est un nouveau type de condition de Victoire. Toutes les autres conditions sont ignorées, et la Victoire est uniquement jugée à la fin de la partie. Pour gagner, les joueurs doivent avoir un maximum de points, et, bien sûr, être toujours vivants.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Distribution de Points[\BOLD]: [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par case de territoire contrôlé [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par pourcentage de population contrôlée par votre équipe [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par pourcentage de culture contrôlée par votre équipe [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par pourcentage de la religion que vous contrôlez (seule la meilleure religion que vous contrôlez est prise en compte) [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par pourcentage de la puissance militaire dont vous disposez [ICON_BULLET] 1 Point par pourcentage des Merveilles [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]construites[COLOR_REVERT] [ICON_BULLET] 30 Points pour chaque Ville ayant atteint le statut Légendaire [ICON_BULLET] 100 Points pour chaque Civilization qui lance un Vaisseau de colonisation.
TEXT.German: Der Meistersieg ist eine völlig neue Siegbedingung, die sich von allen anderen komplett unterscheidet. Wenn er aktiviert wird, werden alle anderen Siegbedingungen ignoriert. Die Siegberechnung erfolgt am Ende der virtuellen Zeit, nicht, wenn ein Spieler ein spezielles Spielziel erreicht hat. Wer bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt überlebt und die meisten Punkte auf seinem Konto hat, gewinnt das Spiel.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Punktevergabe[\BOLD]: [ICON_BULLET] jedes kontrollierte Kartenfeld - 1 Punkt [ICON_BULLET] Anteil an der Weltbevölkerung - 1 Punkt pro Prozentpunkt [ICON_BULLET] Anteil an der gesamten Weltkultur - 1 Punkt pro Prozentpunkt [ICON_BULLET] Anteil der kontrollierten Weltreligion - 1 Punkt pro Prozentpunkt (es wird die wichtigste eigene Religion gewertet) [ICON_BULLET] Anteil an der aktuellen Militärmacht - 1 Punkt pro Prozentpunkt [ICON_BULLET] Anteil an [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]gebauten[COLOR_REVERT] Weltwundern - 1 Punkt pro Prozentpunkt [ICON_BULLET] jede legendäre Stadt - 30 Punkte [ICON_BULLET] ein Raumschiff wurde gestartet - 100 Punkte
TEXT.Italian: La Vittoria master è un tipo completamente diverso di condizione di vittoria. Se abilitata, tutte le altre condizioni di vittoria vengono ignorate. La vittoria è aggiudicata dopo un certo periodo di tempo, non quando un giocatore raggiunge un obiettivo particolare. Per vincere, i giocatori devono avere il maggior numero di punti alla fine del gioco, e, naturalmente, essere ancora vivi.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Distribuzione dei punti[\BOLD]: [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni casella di terra controllata [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni percentuale di popolazione controllato con la squadra [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni percentuale totale della cultura mondiale controllato con la squadra [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni percentuale della religione mondiale controllata dalla squadra (solo la religione più diffusa è tenuta in conto) [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni percentuale di potenza totale accumulata sul mondo al momento [ICON_BULLET] 1 punto per ogni percentuale delle Meraviglie [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT] costruite [COLOR_REVERT] [ICON_BULLET] 30 Punti per ogni città con cultura leggendaria [ICON_BULLET] 100 punti per ogni civiltà che lancia una nave spaziale.
Vittoria master

TEXT.English: Mountains Mod makes several changes to the way moutains work, compared to standard Civilization. These changes are: [ICON_BULLET] Mountains become passible by units with a new technology, [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Mountaineering.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Troops led by a great general may receive a special promotion, [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTIANEER]Mountaineer[\LINK], which allows it to cross Mountains even before researching [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Mountaineering.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Mountains now give a yield of three hammers. [ICON_BULLET] After units can cross peaks, workers can build improvements, like [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]Mines[\LINK] on them. [ICON_BULLET] Mountains may have resources on them. [ICON_BULLET] After researching [LINK=TECH_ALGEBRA]Algebra[\LINK], cities may be built on Mountains. [ICON_BULLET] Certain Buildings, like the [LINK=BUILDING_SKI_RESORT]Ski Resort[\LINK], will require to be built in cities that are located on Mountains.
TEXT.French: Le Mod Montagnes change la façon d'apréhender les montagnes par rapport au jeu Standard. Les Changements: [ICON_BULLET] Les Montagnes deviennent franchissables par les unités uniquement après la recherche de la technologie [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Montagnard.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Les Troupes menées par un général illustre peuvent obtenir une promotion spéciale, [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTIANEER]Montagnard[\LINK], qui leur permet de franchir les Montagnes avant la technologie [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Montagnard.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Les Montagnes permettent l'exploitation de trois [ICON_PRODUCTION]. [ICON_BULLET] Lorsque les montagnes sont franchissables, les Ouvriers peuvent y construire des aménagements, comme les [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]Mines[\LINK]. [ICON_BULLET] Les Montagnes peuvent contenir des Ressources (Or, Argent...) [ICON_BULLET] Après la Recherche [LINK=TECH_ALGEBRA]Algèbre[\LINK], les Villes peuvent être fondées sur des Montagnes. [ICON_BULLET] Certains Bâtiments, comme la [LINK=BUILDING_SKI_RESORT]Station de Sport d'Hiver[\LINK], peuvent avoir comme pré-requis une Ville située sur une Montagne.
TEXT.German: Die Gebirgsmodifikation verändert die Funktionsweise von Gipfeln im Vergleich zum Standard-Spiel. Änderungen sind: [ICON_BULLET] Gipfel können von Einheiten nach der Entdeckung der neuen Technologie [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Bergsteigen[\LINK] betreten werden. [ICON_BULLET] Truppen, die von einem Großen General angeführt werden, können die neue Beförderung [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTIANEER]Bergsteiger[\LINK] erhalten, die es erlaubt, Gipfel schon vor der Entdeckung von [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Bergsteigen[\LINK] zu betreten. [ICON_BULLET] Gipfel liefern nun einen Ertrag von drei [ICON_PRODUCTION]. [ICON_BULLET] Sobald das [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Bergsteigen[\LINK] erforscht wurde, können Bautrupps auf Gipfeln Modernisierungen wie z.B. [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]Minen[\LINK] errichten. [ICON_BULLET] Außerdem sind auf Gipfeln nun auch ab und an Ressourcen vorhanden, die abgebaut werden können. [ICON_BULLET] Wenn die [LINK=TECH_ALGEBRA]Algebra[\LINK] erforscht wurde, sind Siedler in der Lage, Städte auf Gipfeln zu gründen. [ICON_BULLET] Einige Gebäude, wie z.B. das [LINK=BUILDING_SKI_RESORT]Skiresort[\LINK], können nur in solchen Städten gebaut werden.
TEXT.Italian: Il Mod montagne fa cambiamenti significativi al modo in cui le montagne funzionano, in rapporto alla versione standard di Civilization. Questi cambiamenti sono: [ICON_BULLET] Le montagne possono essere attraversate da unità con la ricerca della tecnologia, [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Mountaineering.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Truppe guidate da un grande generale possono ottenere una promozione speciale, [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTIANEER]Mountaineer[\LINK], che permette loro di attraversare le montagne perfino prima di ricercare [LINK=TECH_MOUNTAINEERING]Mountaineering.[\LINK] [ICON_BULLET] Le montagne ora hanno una resa di tre [ICON_PRODUCTION]. [ICON_BULLET] Dopo che le unità possono attraversare le montagne, i lavoratori possono costruire i miglioramenti, come [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]Mines[\LINK]. [ICON_BULLET] Le montagne possono avere risorse. [ICON_BULLET] Dopo aver ricercato [LINK=TECH_ALGEBRA]Algebra[\LINK], le ciità possono essere costruite sulle montagne. [ICON_BULLET] Alcuni edifici, come [LINK=BUILDING_SKI_RESORT]Ski Resort[\LINK], dovranno essere costruiti in città costruite su una montagna.
Movimento

TEXT.English: In Civilization IV, much of your time is spent moving your [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK] around on the map - you send them out to [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Explore[\LINK] new territory; you march them off to battle; and so forth. The basic rules of movement are simple; each unit in the game has a certain number of "movement points" (MPs) which they can expend each turn. Units spend MPs entering a new square; some terrain is more difficult to move through (and thus costs more MPs to enter), some less so, and some is impassable. Certain [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK] cut down the cost of entering certain spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are three basic unit types in the game: land, sea, and air units.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Land Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Land units may move only onto land [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK]. They may not move onto water (unless [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]carried[\LINK] aboard a sea transport unit). Further, land units may not enter [LINK=TERRAIN_PEAK]Peak[\LINK] spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Movement Speed:[\BOLD] Generally, foot soldiers have 1 MP, while horses and powered units have 2 MPs or more. Workers and settlers have 2 MPs. See [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Terrain Costs:[\BOLD] Open terrain - grassland, plains, desert, tundra and ice - cost 1 MP to enter. Hills, jungle, and forests cost 2 MP.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: A unit can always enter a space if it has any MPs left. Thus, a 1 MP unit could enter a forest space, but its move would end there. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK] for details.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Roads and Railroads:[\BOLD] [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Roads[\LINK] negate the movement costs of terrain; all spaces cost 1/2 MP to enter. (When you acquire the [LINK=TECH_ENGINEERING]Engineering[\LINK] technology, the cost goes down to 1/3 MP.) This benefit occurs only when a unit is moving from one road square to another, and only when the square the unit is entering is not within a hostile civ's [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK]. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Railroads[\LINK] are similar to roads, except that railroad squares cost 1/10 MP to enter from other railroad squares.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Rivers:[\BOLD] Rivers negate the effects of roads until you get the [LINK=TECH_CONSTRUCTION]Construction[\LINK] technology; in other words, moving across a river will act the same as if a road is not there at all.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cities[\BOLD] All city spaces are considered to have roads in them. When you have acquired the ability to build railroads, city spaces will have railroads as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Water Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Water units can enter only ocean, coastal, and coastal city squares. They cannot move onto land spaces. Water units cannot enter ice spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Sea Unit Type Limitations:[\BOLD] Early water units - galleys and work boats - cannot enter ocean squares unless those squares are within your cultural borders (or another civilizations's cultural borders if you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]"Open Borders"[\LINK] agreement). Otherwise they are limited to coastal and city spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Movement Speed:[\BOLD] Early water units have 2 MPs; the fastest and most modern water units have as many as 8 MPs. The first civilization to circumnavigate the globe will also receive a +1 MP bonus to all of its water units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Terrain Costs:[\BOLD] All coastal/ocean spaces cost 1 MP to enter. Ice spaces are impassable.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Air Units[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In general, air units can enter both land and water spaces, including impassable ice and peak spaces. All spaces cost 1 MP for air units to enter. See [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Air Units[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Promotions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotions[\LINK] allow units to move faster through certain terrain types or grant them extra MPs altogether. For example, the Mobility promotion allows mounted and armored units to move faster through rough terrain and the Navigation promotions grant water units extra MPs.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Borders on Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Your units can move freely within your territory and unclaimed territory, as well as through territory of civilizations with whom you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Open Borders[\LINK] treaty. If you enter territory of a civilization without such a treaty, you declare war on that civ. You do not get the benefits of roads or rails when moving into enemy territory.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Other Units on Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Other friendly or neutral units do not affect your units' movement at all; in other words, your units can move onto the same space as a foreign unit without attacking it. However, if your unit enters a space containing an enemy unit, your unit will initiate [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK] with the enemy.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Controlling Your Units[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can use your mouse or keyboard to move your units. See the game controls section of the manual to learn how to "activate" units and tell them where you want them to go.
TEXT.French: Dans Civilization IV, vous consacrerez une grande partie de votre temps à déplacer vos [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unités[\LINK] sur la carte, pour [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]explorer[\LINK] de nouveaux territoires, partir en guerre, etc. Les règles de base du déplacement sont simples: chaque unité dispose à chaque tour d'un certain nombre de "points de mouvement" (PM). Elles en utilisent chaque fois qu'elles entrent sur une nouvelle case. Certains types de terrains sont plus difficiles à traverser (et coûtent davantage de PM), d'autres moins, et quelques-uns sont infranchissables. Des [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]améliorations[\LINK] permettent de diminuer le coût en PM pour entrer sur certaines cases.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il y a trois principales catégories d'unité dans le jeu: les unités terrestres, maritimes et aériennes.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Déplacement terrestre[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les unités terrestres ne peuvent se déplacer que sur les [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]terrains[\LINK]. Elles ne peuvent aller sur l'eau, à moins d'être [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]transportées[\LINK] par des bateaux de transport.
